title: 110_hr2133
content: The Act is titled the "Small Business Investment and Promotion Act of 2007" and includes a temporary credit against income tax for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs. The Act provides an excessive fuel cost credit for eligible taxpayers based on the difference between the amount paid for creditable fuel and the adjusted base price determined by the Secretary. The Act offers an excessive fuel cost credit to eligible taxpayers based on the difference between the amount paid for fuel and the adjusted base price determined by the Secretary, using inflation-adjusted prices from Labor Day 2004. Eligibility is determined based on the region where the fuel was purchased, with inflation adjustments made using estimates of the monthly Consumer Price Index. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to individuals engaged in farming, commercial fishing, or small businesses with up to 50 employees. 'Creditable fuel' includes gasoline and diesel fuel. The text discusses eligible taxpayers being able to elect a standard mileage allowance of 60 cents per mile for certain fuels purchased within a 2-year period. The credit is part of the general business credit. The text introduces a new paragraph (32) regarding the excessive fuel cost credit for eligible taxpayers defined in section 45O(c). A clerical amendment is also made to the table of sections. The text introduces a temporary credit for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs. It also includes a permanent extension of the research credit by amending sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of qualified restaurant property, qualified retail improvement property, and certain systems installed in nonresidential buildings as 15-year property for purposes of depreciation deduction. The text discusses amending the Internal Revenue Code to include qualified restaurant property, qualified retail improvement property, and certain systems in nonresidential buildings as 15-year property for depreciation deduction. The text discusses adding qualified retail improvement property as 15-year property for depreciation deduction in nonresidential buildings. The text discusses the criteria for real property to qualify for depreciation deduction, including being open to the public, used by a business with under 50 employees, and placed in service after 3 years. It excludes improvements related to building enlargement. The text discusses criteria for real property to qualify for depreciation deduction, excluding improvements related to building enlargement or internal structural framework. It also mentions the requirement to use the straight-line method and alternative systems for certain property classes. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. Authorized appropriations for various programs under the Small Business Act and the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 include $145 million for the Advanced Technology Program, $8 million for SCORE, $140 million for Small Business Development Centers, and funding for the Manufacturing Extension Partnership. For the Manufacturing Extension Partnership program, $120 million is allocated for fiscal year 2008 and $125 million for fiscal year 2009. For the Women's Business Center Program, $15.5 million is authorized for fiscal year 2008 and $16 million for fiscal year 2009. SEC. 6. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON FUNDING FOR SMALL BUSINESS PROGRAMS. Congress should appropriate $79,000,000 for the 7(a) Loan Program and funds for various other small business programs at authorized levels. SEC. 7. SMALL BUSINESS CONTRACTING GOAL. SEC. 7. SMALL BUSINESS CONTRACTING GOAL. Amends the Small Business Act to include contracts performed overseas in the small business contracting goal. Effective for fiscal years starting after September 30, 2007.
